newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: New IBM, Lotus software to tap Asian retail.
newsitem.headline: New IBM, Lotus software to tap Asian retail.

text.p: A new Web software offered by IBM and its Lotus Development unit expects to capitalise on a burst in demand by Asian businesses for the internet, software company officials said at a launch on Wednesday.
"There is massive growth out here. This is the layer of growth we will be able to take advantage of," Charlie Ill, IBM's general manager of software for Asia Pacific, said.
IBM's revenue from networking and distribution of computing software products grew more than 30 percent last year, due to rising demand for electronic business applications.

The launch of the product, designed to enable IBM to expand its offerings in the fastest-growing segment of its software business, is occurring at a time when its corporate customers and others are turning to the Web for business opportunities.
"I can tell you that Japan has the highest growth rate in internet servers worldwide," Ill said, adding that Japan last year overtook Germany in growth rates.
He said Asian business will likely reap rewards similar to those of U.S. companies using internet and intranet for retail and other transactions.
The single largest concern for internet and intranet users was security, but this problem would be partly resolved by Secure Electronic Transaction (SET) technology, Ill said.
"It's an industry standard by MasterCard and Visa where two parties agree to use a bank...it's like a tripartite agreement," said Patricia Yim, manager for ASEAN-South Asia software.
She said that electronic transfer of funds, such as at many retail outlets and the rise in credit card usuage, were examples of changing habits and modes of business.
IBM's new Network Computing Framework strategy and launch of new Web server software and other products helps link a company's business and data with the global access of the Web.
It provides for establishing a Web site, supporting message handling on an intranet and managing business over the internet, including electronic transfer of funds, IBM officials said.
